member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.MessageTransform
member.summary: Transforms a model specified in terms of channels into the set of message passing operations required to perform inference in that model.
member.remarks: The message passing transform does the following operations: - converts channel declarations into pairs of variables for forwards and backwards messages along that channel. - initalises message arrays using the appropriate message prototypes - message prototypes may be different for backward and forward directions - the algorithm determines the message prototypes in a call to GetMessagePrototypes - default message prototype is the marginal prototype - converts method calls into sets of operator method calls - keeps track of all inter-operator dependencies, as these are needed by the scheduler

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.MessageTransform.MessageInfo
member.summary: Describes a message in a message-passing program.
member.remarks:
A message is a channel paired with a direction (either forwards or backwards). A message can be labelled as an "output" to mean it is the result of inference. When a random variable has multiple uses, all uses are labelled with the same MessageInfo.
If the channel is in a plate, we need to distinguish between the case of one message per each plate instance versus one message for the entire plate.
If the channel is an array type, then there are three possible message types: 1. If the channel is in a plate, then so is the message. 2. If the channel is not in a plate, but individual messages are desired for each array element. If the channel is inside a plate, in which case it stores for an array of distributions.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.MessageTransform.MessageInfo.FindChannelInfo(MicrosoftResearch.Transforms.BasicTransformContext,MicrosoftResearch.Transforms.CodeModel.Interfaces.IExpression)
member.summary: Set the channelInfo field via the attributes applied to channelRef.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Transforms.CodeBuilder.StaticGenericMethod(System.Delegate,System.Type[],MicrosoftResearch.Transforms.CodeModel.Interfaces.IExpression[])
member.summary: Creates a call to a static generic method by replacing the type arguments in the method referred to by the delegate with the specified arguments. This allows the method to be referred to statically even when the generic arguments are not known at compile-time. By convention, the type arguments of the delegate method should be object or the highest level class which satisifies the type constraints.

member.summary: Creates a call to a static generic method by replacing the type arguments in the method referred to by the delegate with the specified arguments. By convention, the type arguments of the delegate method should be object or the highest level class which satisifies the type constraints.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.Scheduling2Transform.AssignLabelsByMinCut
member.summary: Rotate the back edges around each cycle to minimize the number of back edges with Required annotations
member.remarks: Algorithm: Visit each back edge and see if there is a cut of forward edges that separates it from its descendant back edges. If the cut is smaller than its ancestor back edges, then make the cut backward and the ancestors forward. The number of back edges on each cycle is preserved, while the total number of back edges decreases at each step.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.MethodReference.#ctor(System.Type,System.String,System.Type[])
member.summary: Construct a method reference from a name and optional types.
member.param: The name must specify the number of generic type parameters via the syntax <> or <,> etc.
An array of types, which may contain null as a wildcard.
member.remarks:
If the method is generic with n type parameters, then the first n parameterTypes are interpreted as type arguments. These can be null to allow arbitrary type arguments. Examples:
new MethodReference(typeof(Array),"Copy",typeof(Array),typeof(Array),typeof(Int32)) This selects the first overload of the non-generic method .
new MethodReference(typeof(Array),"Copy",null,null,typeof(Int32)) This selects the same method as above, since the number of parameters and the type of the third parameter disambiguate the overload.
new MethodReference(typeof(Array),"Find") This throws an exception since is a generic method only.
new MethodReference(typeof(Array),"Find<>") This selects the generic method , without specifying any type arguments or parameter types. This method is not overloaded so no disambiguation via parameter types is needed.
new MethodReference(typeof(Array),"Find<>",null) This is equivalent to the above. Adding two more nulls (corresponding to the two parameters of Find) would also be equivalent.
new MethodReference(typeof(Array),"Find<>",typeof(int)) This selects the generic method , with type argument set to int. No parameter types are specified. This method is not overloaded so no disambiguation via parameter types is needed.
new MethodReference(typeof(Array),"FindIndex<>",typeof(int),typeof(int[]),typeof(Predicate<int>)) This selects the first overload of the generic method , with type argument set to int.
new MethodReference(typeof(Array),"FindIndex<>",typeof(int),null,null) This selects the same method as above, since the number of parameters (two) disambiguates the overload.
new MethodReference(typeof(Array),"FindIndex<>",null,null,null) This selects the first overload of the generic method , without specializing on a type argument.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.MethodReference.GetMethodInfo
member.summary: Convert the MethodReference into a concrete MethodInfo.
member.exception: No methods of this.Type match the specification.
More than one method matches (due to wildcards in the MethodReference).
A type argument does not satisfy the constraints of the generic method definition.

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Models.SharedVariable`1
member.summary: Abstract base class for shared variables. Shared variables allow a model to be split into submodels in which variables are shared. Each submodel can have many copies.
member.remarks: A typical use of this is for large data sets where the likelihood parts of the model cannot all fit in memory. The solution is to divide the data into chunks (or 'batches'), and specify a single submodel which includes the likelihood factors and variables for one chunk, along with the shared parameters; the number of copies of the submodel is set to the number of chunks. In a related pattern, there are one or more additional submodels for defining the parameter variables.

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Models.SharedVariable`2
member.summary: A helper class that represents a variable which is shared between multiple models. For example, where a very large model has been divided into sections corresponding to batches of data, an instance of this class can be used to help learn each parameter shared between the batches.

remarks.para: Shared variables are used as follows. First the shared variable is created with a prior distribution. Then a copy is created for each model using the method. Each model has a BatchCount which is the number of data batches you want to process with that model. Before performing inference in each model and batch, should be called for each shared variable. After all shared variables have their inputs set, should then be called for each model and batch. These two steps are done automatically by . For inference to converge, you must loop multiple times through all the models, calling or SetInput/InferOutput each time. At any point the current marginal of the shared variable can be retrieved using .

In some situations, shared variables cannot be created directly from a prior distribution, for example in a hierarchical model. In these situations, create the shared variable with a uniform prior, and use to define the variable.
A shared variable which calculates evidence must be treated as a special case; such variables can be marked using , and the evidence is recovered using

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Graphs.PseudoPeripheralSearch`1
member.summary: Searches for a pair of pseudo-peripheral nodes in a graph.
member.remarks: The nodes (start,end) form a pseudo-peripheral pair if end is the furthest node from start and start is the furthest node from end. If the distance is maximal over all such pairs, then the nodes are peripheral. This class does not guarantee that the pair is peripheral, only pseudo-peripheral. In a directed graph, distance from start is measured forward and distance from end is measured backward.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Graphs.PseudoPeripheralSearch`1.SearchFrom(`0@,`0@)
member.summary: Find a pseudo-peripheral pair.
member.param: On entry, holds an initial seed for the search. On return, holds the start node of the pair.
On return, holds the end node of the pair.
member.remarks: Regardless of the seed node provided, a pseudo-peripheral pair will always be found. However the seed can affect the quality of the pair (i.e. how distant they are).

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Graphs.IGraph`1
member.summary: A graph of nodes and edges.
member.typeparam: The type of a node handle.

remarks.p: This interface is intended for use by generic algorithms which can operate on any graph type. Nodes are treated as opaque handles, generated by the graph, which only the graph knows how to resolve. Some graph types might represent nodes as objects with edge data; other graphs might use integer indices or even strings.

This interface can be used for both directed and undirected graphs, though the methods only provide undirected information (i.e. all neighbors rather than sources vs. targets). See for methods to modify a graph, and to get directed edge information. In this interface, edges are represented implicitly as (source, target) pairs. See for methods using explicit edge handles.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Graphs.IGraph`1.NeighborCount(`0)
member.summary: Number of adjacent nodes.
member.returns: The number of nodes adjacent to .
member.remarks: For a directed graph, this is the number of sources (parents) plus the number of targets (children) of

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Graphs.IGraph`1.NeighborsOf(`0)
member.summary: Adjacent nodes.
member.remarks: For a directed graph, this is the sources (parents) and targets (children) of , in any order.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Graphs.IGraph`1.ContainsEdge(`0,`0)
member.summary: Test for an edge.
member.returns: True if an edge exists from to
member.remarks: For some graph types, source and target are not required to be nodes in the graph. That is, ContainsEdge(source,target) can be true even if Nodes.Contains(source) is false.

member.name: P:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Graphs.IGraph`1.Nodes
member.summary: Collection of node handles.
member.remarks: The methods Add(NodeType) and Contains(NodeType) which are defined by are not necessarily supported (in order to use them, you would have to have a valid node handle, which implies the node is already in the graph). The methods Remove(NodeType) and Clear() are only supported by mutable graphs, and they are only guaranteed to remove node handles from the Nodes collection; the edges connected to those nodes may still exist in the graph.

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Graphs.IndexedGraphWrapper`2
member.summary: Create a graph from a collection of nodes and corresponding adjacency data.
member.typeparam: The type of a node handle.
The type of a node data structure.

remarks.para: This class creates a directed graph object from a collection of node handles and data objects. The data object is assumed to hold the adjacency information for the handles, in the form of a delegate sourcesOfNode(data) which returns a collection of node handles. Each node is given an integer index. Using these integers you can attach additional data to the graph via CreateNodeData which returns an array.

In the simplest case, NodeInfo can be the same as Node in which case this class just stores a mapping from nodes to integers and vice versa. (The delegate infoOfNode would simply return its argument.) More generally, NodeInfo can store cached information about the node.

member.name: F:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Graphs.IndexedGraphWrapper`2.indexOfNode
member.summary: Provides an index (into info[]) for each node.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Dynamic.Binding
member.summary: Represents the type parameters and argument conversions needed to invoke a method.

remarks.para: Given a generic method definition and a list of arguments, a Binding represents the additional information needed to invoke the method with those arguments. Specifically, it stores a list of type parameters (possibly empty if the method is not generic) and a list of conversions, one for each argument. Note that Bindings are not unique, e.g. a type parameter might be instantiated in several different ways, yet still compatible with the given arguments. Each of these choices is a different Binding.
This class allows you to find the Binding which is 'best' in the sense of being the most specific. The < operator can be used to compare the specificity of Bindings.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Dynamic.GenericParameterFactory.SelfReference`1
member.summary: Used in generic parameter constraints to refer to the type being defined.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Dynamic.GenericParameterFactory.Constraints.IsAssignableFrom(Microsoft.Dynamic.GenericParameterFactory.Constraints)
member.summary: True if that is more constrained than this.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Dynamic.GenericParameterFactory.MakeGenericParameter(System.String,Microsoft.Dynamic.GenericParameterFactory.Constraints)
member.summary: Make a generic type parameter with the given constraints.
member.remarks: Algorithm: The type parameter is constructed by dynamically generating a type with a generic method. For example: class Parent { void method<U>() where U : IList<int> {} } If the constraints refer to other type parameters, placeholders are added to the parent type. For example: class Parent<T> { void method<U>() where U : IList<T> {} } The parent type is then specialized on the actual type parameters appearing in the constraints. The type parameter U is returned.

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.GateTransform
member.summary: Handles gates in the MSL, as represented by if statements and switch statements.
member.remarks:
This transform affects: - references to variables declared outside of an if/switch statement The transform replaces the variable with different clones on each branch. A Gate.Enter factor is added at the start relating the clones to the original.
- variables defined in all branches of an if/switch statement The transform replaces the variable with different clones in each branch. A Gate.Exit factor is added at the end relating the clones to the original.

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Graphs.MinCut`2
member.summary: Finds a minimum edge cut to separate a set of sources from a set of sinks

remarks.para: A node can be both a source and a sink. In this case, edges into the node are considered toward the sink and edges out of the node are considered from the source. Thus the algorithm will cut all paths from the node back to itself.

By modifying IsSinkEdge, certain edges can be labelled as "sink edges". These edges are treated as if their target was a sink node. Making a node both a source and sink is equivalent to making it a source and labelling its inward edges as sink edges.

The implementation uses the preflow-push algorithm, modified to return the minimum cut, as described by Jianxiu Hao and James B. Orlin, "A faster algorithm for finding the minimum cut in a directed graph", Journal of Algorithms 17: 424--446 (1994).

This algorithm can sometimes be very slow for certain choices of the capacities. This seems to be caused by loss of precision in the float calculations, e.g. when a edge with capacity 1e-8 pushes flow into an edge with capacity 1e+8.

member.name: F:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Graphs.MinCut`2.reverseCapacity
member.summary: Capacity of an edge in the reverse direction (default 0)

member.summary: The set of source nodes

member.summary: The set of sink nodes

member.name: F:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Graphs.MinCut`2.IsSinkEdge
member.summary: The set of sink edges

member.summary: A cache of the nodes at a given distanceToSink

member.summary: The flow in the direction of the edge (always between -reverseCapacity and the capacity)

member.summary: A cache of (inward flow - outward flow)

member.summary: The nodes on the source side of the cut

member.summary: All nodes that are not in the sourceGroup, not a sink, and have inward flow > outward flow

member.summary: Compute the min cut and return all nodes connected to any source
member.returns: The set of all nodes connected to any source after removing the min cut edges

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Graphs.ILabeledCollection`2
member.summary: A collection which is the union of labeled subcollections.

remarks.p: This interface corresponds to an inverted index, where each label maps to a subset of items. This is unlike an IDictionary, where each key maps to a single item. When the labels are sparse, an inverted index is more efficient than attaching a label to each item and searching through the items. The subcollections may overlap.

Add(ItemType) is equivalent to using the default label, which may be default(LabelType) or some other value such as an empty string (""). The other ICollection methods, such as Count and Clear, apply to all items regardless of label.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Graphs.ILabeledCollection`2.WithLabel(`1)
member.summary: Get a subcollection.
member.param: The label of an existing subcollection or a subcollection to be created.
member.remarks: If the subcollection already exists, it is returned. Otherwise, a new subcollection is created and returned. The result is mutable. Some LabeledCollection classes may not allow certain labels.
member.exception: If the label is not allowed by the collection.

member.name: P:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Graphs.ILabeledCollection`2.Labels
member.summary: The labels of the subcollections.
member.remarks: Labels must be unique. The returned collection must not be modified.

member.summary: A base class for LabeledCollection wrapper classes.
member.remarks: This class makes it easy to write decorators for LabeledCollections.

member.param: The name of a field, property, event, instance method, or static method.
The object whose member to invoke. Ignored for a static field or property. If target is non-null, then it is provided as the first argument to a static method.
Can be empty or null. Empty means a function call with no arguments. null means get the member itself.
member.returns: The result of the invocation. For SetField/SetProperty the result is null.

remarks.para: This routine is patterned after Type.InvokeMember. flags must specify Instance, Static, or both.
If flags contains CreateInstance, then name is ignored and a constructor is invoked.

If memberName names a field/property and flags contains SetField/SetProperty, then the field/property's value is changed to args[args.Length-1]. If args.Length > 1, the field/property is indexed by args[0:(args.Length-2)].

If memberName names a field/property and flags contains GetField/GetProperty, then the field/property's value is returned. If args != null and the field/property is a delegate, then it is invoked with args. Otherwise if args != null, the field/property is indexed by args.
If memberName names an event and flags contains GetField, then the event's EventInfo is returned. If args != null, then the event is raised with args.

If memberName names a method and flags contains InvokeMethod, then it is invoked with args. A static method is invoked with target and args. If args == null, then the result is a DelegateGroup containing all overloads of the method.
Other flag values are implemented as in Type.InvokeMember. In each case, overloading is resolved by matching the argument types, possibly with conversions.

If a matching member is not found, the interfaces of the type are also searched. As a last resort, if the memberName is op_Equality or op_Inequality, then a default implementation is provided (as in C#).

member.name: M:Microsoft.Dynamic.Invoker.InvokeMemberCodePrep(System.Type,System.String,System.Reflection.BindingFlags,System.Type,System.Type[])
member.summary: Get a CodeOperator which generates code for invoking a member.
member.returns: A CodeExpressionOperator which takes a target object expression and argument value expressions, and returns an expression, or a CodeStatementOperator which returns a statement.
member.remarks: This is effectively a partially-evaluated version of InvokeMember. The return type is object since delegates aren't polymorphic.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Dynamic.Invoker.InvokeCodePrep(System.Reflection.MethodBase[],System.Type,System.Type[])
member.summary: Get a CodeOperator which generates code to invoke the method which best matches the argument types.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Dynamic.Invoker.InvokeMemberPrep(System.Type,System.String,System.Reflection.BindingFlags,System.Type,System.Type[])
member.summary: Get a delegate which invokes a member.
member.returns: A delegate which takes a target object and argument values, and returns the same value as InvokeMember, but more efficiently.
member.remarks: This is effectively a partially-evaluated version of InvokeMember.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.GateAnalysisTransform.CouldBeEqual(MicrosoftResearch.Transforms.CodeModel.Interfaces.IExpression,MicrosoftResearch.Transforms.CodeModel.Interfaces.IExpression)
member.summary: Returns true if the expressions could have the same value.
member.remarks: Examples: (0,i) = true for any variable i (0,1) = false (i,j) = true for any variables i and j (i,i-1) = false (i-1,i-2) = false (i,j-1) = true

member.summary: Returns an expression equal to expr1 and expr2 under their respective bindings, or null if the expressions are not equal.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.GateAnalysisTransform.AnyIndex
member.summary: Used only in ArrayIndexerExpressions, to represent a wildcard.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.GateAnalysisTransform.GetCommonParent(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.ExpressionWithBindings,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.ExpressionWithBindings,System.Boolean@)
member.summary: Return the common parent of the two expressions, and indicate if the expressions overlap
member.remarks: When finding the common parent, we want to preserve any array slicing. Indexing brackets are not removed if present in both expressions. Mismatching indices are replaced by AnyIndex. Examples: i = loop index inside the gate block j = loop index outside the gate block, or a method parameter (a,a[i]) => (a,true) (a,a[j]) => (a,true) (a[i],a[0]) => (a[*],true) (a[i],a[j]) => (a[*],true) (a[j],a[0]) => (a[*],assumeMatch) (a[0],a[1]) => (a[*],false) (a[0][0],a[1][0]) => (a[*][0],false) (a[0][0],a[1][1]) => (a[*][*],false)

member.summary: Returns a prefix of expr1 that matches expr2, where anything matches AnyItem. The indices that matched AnyItem are returned.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.SchedulingTransform.DecayingCost(System.Single,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a cost function where more available is always better, and less missing breaks ties.
member.param: An integer >= 1. Preferably a power of two.
member.returns: A cost in the range 0 to maxCost-1.
member.remarks: Result is 0 if missing is 0. Result is maxCost-1 only if available=0 and missing >= log2(maxCost).

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Models.Variable
member.summary: A variable in a model
member.remarks: Variables can be base or derived. A base Variable is explicitly declared as a variable in MSL. A derived Variable is simply an expression built from variables. For example, the expression a[i] is a derived Variable called an item variable. Every method that manipulates Variable objects must be aware of this distinction.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Models.Variable.IsDefinedInContext(System.Collections.Generic.List{MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Models.ConditionBlock})
member.summary: True if the variable is defined in the given condition context.
member.remarks: Suppose we have x.SetTo(def) inside [c==0][d==0] Then x.IsDefinedInContext is true inside [c==0][d==0], [c==0][d==0][e==0], [c==0], and nothing. x.IsDefinedInContext is false inside [c==0][d==1] and [c==1]. In other words, IsDefinedInContext is true when the context is a prefix of the definition context, or when the definition context is a prefix of the context.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Models.Variable.Beta(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Creates a Beta-distributed random variable from initial success/failure counts.
member.returns: Returns a Beta-distributed random variable that is statistically defined by Beta(trueCount,falseCount).
member.remarks: The distribution's formula is prob(x) = (Gamma(trueCount+falseCount)/Gamma(trueCount)/Gamma(falseCount)) x^{trueCount-1} (1-x)^(falseCount-1) where x is between [0, 1].

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Models.Variable.If(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Models.Variable{System.Boolean})
member.summary: Opens a stochastic if statement, active when the argument is true.
member.remarks: This method should be used as the argument to a using() statement, so that the if statement is automatically closed. If this is not possible, the returned IfBlock must be closed manually by calling CloseBlock().
member.param: The condition of the if block
member.returns: An IfBlock object which must be closed before inference is performed.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Models.Variable.IfNot(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Models.Variable{System.Boolean})
member.summary: Opens a stochastic if statement, active when the argument is false.
member.remarks: This method should be used as the argument to a using() statement, so that the if statement is automatically closed. If this is not possible, the returned IfBlock must be closed manually by calling CloseBlock().
member.param: The condition of the if block
member.returns: An IfBlock object which must be closed before inference is performed.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Models.Variable.Case(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Models.Variable{System.Int32},System.Int32)
member.summary: Opens a stochastic case statement, active when the integer argument has the specified value.
member.remarks: This method should be used as the argument to a using() statement, so that the if statement is automatically closed. If this is not possible, the returned CaseBlock must be closed manually by calling CloseBlock().
member.param: The condition of the case block
The value of the condition for which the block is active
member.returns: A CaseBlock object which must be closed before inference is performed.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Models.Variable.CloseAllBlocks
member.summary: Close blocks in order to recover from exceptions

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Models.Variable.Switch(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Models.Variable{System.Int32})
member.summary: Opens a stochastic switch statement using the specified condition variable. This is equivalent to creating a set of identical Variable.Case() statements for each value of i. Within a switch block, you can use the variable i as an array index.
member.remarks: This method should be used as the argument to a using() statement, so that the if statement is automatically closed. If this is not possible, the returned SwitchBlock must be closed manually by calling CloseBlock().
member.param: The condition of the switch block
member.returns: A SwitchBlock object which must be closed before inference is performed.

member.name: P:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Models.Variable.Definition
member.summary: Gets the definition of this variable in the current context. Will return null if the variable is undefined or if it is only defined in a subcontext (such as an If or Switch).

member.name: P:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Models.Variable.IsDefined
member.summary: True if the variable is defined in the current condition context.
member.remarks: Suppose we have x.SetTo(def) inside [c==0][d==0] Then x.IsDefined is true inside [c==0][d==0], [c==0][d==0][e==0], [c==0], and nothing. x.IsDefined is false inside [c==0][d==1] and [c==1]. In other words, x.IsDefined is true when the current condition context is a prefix of the definition context, or when the definition context is a prefix of the current condition context.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Models.Variable`1.op_Equality(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Models.Variable{`0},MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Models.Variable{`0})
member.summary: Returns a new variable that is true when two variables are equal.
member.returns: A new variable that is true when a and b are equal.
member.remarks:
If you want to test if a variable object points to null, or if two variable objects are the same object, then cast to object first and use reference equality, like so:
if((object)var == null) ...
if((object)var1 == (object)var2) ...
if(object.ReferenceEquals(var1,var2)) ...

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Models.Variable`1.op_Equality(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Models.Variable{`0},`0)
member.summary: Returns a new variable that is true when a variable equals a given value.
member.returns: A new variable that is true when a equals b.
member.remarks: If you want to test if a variable object points to null, then cast to object first and use reference equality, like so: if((object)var == null) ...

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Models.Variable`1.op_Inequality(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Models.Variable{`0},MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Models.Variable{`0})
member.summary: Returns a new variable that is true when two variables are not equal.
member.returns: A new variable that is true when a and b are not equal.
member.remarks:
If you want to test if a variable object does not point to null, or if two variable objects are not the same object, then cast to object first and use reference equality, like so:
if((object)var != null) ...
if((object)var1 != (object)var2) ...
if(!object.ReferenceEquals(var1,var2)) ...

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Models.Variable`1.op_Inequality(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Models.Variable{`0},`0)
member.summary: Returns a new variable that is true when a variable does not equal a given value.
member.returns: A new variable that is true when a does not equal b.
member.remarks: If you want to test if a variable object does not point to null, then cast to object first and use reference equality, like so: if((object)var != null) ...

member.name: T:Microsoft.Dynamic.ISerializerSink`1
member.summary: An interface for defining objects.
member.remarks:
The sink has 5 states:
waiting to set constructor parameter n.
waiting to set an unnamed property.
waiting to set a named property.
waiting to set index n of an indexed property.
waiting to set the value of an indexed property. StartObject will push the state on the stack and enter state 1 or 2. SetProperty will change from state 2->3. In other states it throws an exception. SetIndexedProperty will change from state 2,3->4. In other states it throws an exception. WriteLiteral/WriteReference will change from state 1->1 or 1->2, 2->2, 3->2, 4->4 or 4->5, 5->2. EndObject will pop the state from the stack.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Dynamic.ISerializerSink`1.WriteLiteral(System.Object)
member.summary: Set the current property (or property index or constructor parameter) to a literal value.
member.remarks: Must support primitive types, string, and int[].

member.name: M:Microsoft.Dynamic.ISerializerSink`1.SetProperty(System.String)
member.summary: Use the following value as a property value.
member.param: The name of the property to set.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Dynamic.ISerializerSink`1.SetIndexedProperty(System.Int32)
member.summary: Use the following values as indices, followed by a property value.
member.remarks: The next +1 values written will be used to define the property. The first values will be the index, and the last one will be the property value.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Transforms.CodeRecognizer.IsBeingMutated(MicrosoftResearch.Transforms.BasicTransformContext,MicrosoftResearch.Transforms.CodeModel.Interfaces.IExpression)
member.summary: Returns true if the expression is being mutated in the given context. For example, this will be true if the expression is the LHS of an assignment, or the argument to an 'out' parameter.

Returns true if mutating the first expression would affect the value of the second. For example, if the first expression is 'x' and the second is 'x[1]' the answer is true. If the first expression is 'x[0]' and the second is 'x[1]' the answer is false.
If 'mutatesWithinOnly' is true, the result will only be true if the first expression mutates all or part of the second, but nothing else. For example, if the first is 'x[0]' and the second is 'x' the result is true but not if the first is 'x' and the second 'x[0]'.
member.param: Lower bounds on the index variables in mutated
Lower bounds on the index variables in affected
Modified to contain indexing offsets necessary for a match
Modified to contain extra indices at the end of mutated that are not in affected

member.summary: Returns true if the first expression is equal to, or a subarray or element of the second expression. For example, x, x[0], x[0][0] are all subarrays of x, but x[1] is not part of x[0].

member.summary: Sets VariableInformation.isStochastic, converts constants in random contexts into distributions, and attaches MarginalPrototype attributes.
member.remarks: DistributionAnalysis must be part of this transform in order to correctly convert constants. Otherwise, you would have to execute multiple rounds of StocAnalysis and DistributionAnalysis.

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.IterationTransform
member.summary: Find statements with cyclic dependencies and place them in while loops. Statements not in loops, and the loops themselves, are topologically sorted. DependencyInformation.IsUniform is updated based on this ordering. Statements within while loops have arbitrary order.

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.IterationStatement
member.summary: Attached to a dummy statement used to put all DependsOnIteration statements in the same loop

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.DoNotSchedule
member.summary: Attached to a while loop to tell the scheduler not to process it

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.OutputSource
member.summary: Attached to source statements of output statements

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.HoistingTransform
member.summary: Optimises computation by moving operations computed inside a loop to outside of the loop where possible. PREREQUISITE: Variable declarations must have 'Containers' attributes indicating the containers they belong to.

member.name: F:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.HoistingTransform.hoistVarOfInitializer
member.summary: For each variable whose initializer has been hoisted, stores a reference expression for the hoist variable.

member.name: F:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.HoistingTransform.containers
member.summary: Collects containers of expressions

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.HoistingTransform.ConvertAssign(MicrosoftResearch.Transforms.CodeModel.Interfaces.IAssignExpression)
member.summary: Looks for method invocations where the arguments have fewer indices than the LHS of the assignment. If the method is pure and not stochastic, then saves computation by doing it only once, outside the loops corresponding to the excess indices.
Define a hoist variable for the rhs and return an assignment of iae.Target to SimpleCopy(hoist)

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.HoistingTransform.ConvertVariableDeclExpr(MicrosoftResearch.Transforms.CodeModel.Interfaces.IVariableDeclarationExpression)
member.summary: Record the containers that a variable is declared in. Must be done in this transform because a loop variable may have many declarations, each in a different container.

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.DoesNotHaveInitializer
member.summary: When attached to a message declaration, indicates that the message has no initializer statement, only update statements.

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.BrokenLoop
member.summary: When attached to a loop statement, indicates that the loop contains a break or continue statement.

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.Channel2Transform
member.summary: Transforms variable references into channels, by duplicating variables into uses arrays. A channel is a variable which is assigned once and referenced only once. It corresponds to an edge in a factor graph.

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.Channel2Transform.VariableToChannelInformation
member.summary: Records information about the variable to channel transformation.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.Channel2Transform.ConvertFor(MicrosoftResearch.Transforms.CodeModel.Interfaces.IForStatement)
member.summary: Only converts the contained statements in a for loop, leaving the initializer, condition and increment statements unchanged.
member.remarks: This method includes a number of checks to ensure the loop is valid e.g. that the initializer, condition and increment are all of the appropriate form.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Transforms.Quoter.TryQuoteConstructable(System.Object,MicrosoftResearch.Transforms.CodeModel.Interfaces.IExpression@,System.String,System.Type)
member.summary: Trys to quote an object using any Construction attributes that it is annotated with.
member.remarks: This method can be used to quote a different object that the one passed in, by using 'useWhenOverride'. For example, setting it to 'IsUniform' will mean that the value will be quoted as if 'IsUniform' were true. In general, this will result in quoting the closest value that meets the specified condition.
member.param: The quoted expression or null if quoting failed
Overrides which construction attribute to use, to quote The type of the value to quote or null to use value.GetType() the object passed in modified to have the condition be true

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.VariableInformation.SetMarginalPrototypeFromAttribute(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.MarginalPrototype)
member.summary: Sets the marginal prototype from a supplied MarginalPrototype attribute. If this is null, attempts to set the marginal prototype automatically.
Create an array of this variable type, optionally after slicing it.
member.param: Length of the array. May be null.
Name of a new integer variable used to index the array. May be null if arraySize is null.
Indices applied to this, before creating the array. May be null. May contain wildcards.
Loop variables to use for wildcards. May be null if there are no wildcards.
member.remarks: The new array is indexed by wildcards first, then newIndexVar, then the indices remaining from the original array. For example, if original array is indexed [i,j][k,l][m,n] and indices = [*,*][3,*] then the new array is indexed [wildcard0,wildcard1][wildcard2][newIndexVar][m,n] where sizes and marginalPrototype have expressions replaced according to (i=wildcard0, j=wildcard1, k=3, l=wildcard2).
member.returns: A new array of depth (arraySize != null) + ArrayDepth - indices.Count + wildcardVars.Count

member.summary: Create a slice of this variable array, where all indices up to a certain depth are given.
member.param: Name of the new variable array
Expressions used to index the variable array.
member.returns: The declaration of the new variable.
member.remarks: For example, suppose we want to slice a[i][2][j][k] into b[j][k]. Then ="b", =[i][2].

member.summary: Replace all indexVars which appear in expr with the given indices.
member.param: A list of lists of index expressions (one list for each indexing bracket).
Expressions used to replace wildcards. May be null if there are no wildcards.

member.name: P:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.VariableInformation.ArrayDepth
member.summary: Returns the array depth of this variable. This is the number of pairs of square brackets needed to fully index the variable i.e. 0 for a non-array, 1 for x[] or x[,], 2 for x[][] or x[,][] or x[,][,] etc.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.FactorManager.FactorInfo.OutputIsDeterministic(System.Collections.Generic.IDictionary{System.String,System.Type})
member.summary: True if the factor is deterministic and all arguments to the factor are deterministic types.
member.param: A mapping from factor arguments to message types. Missing entries imply no constraint. Can be null.
member.remarks: If the result is true, then GetMessageFcnInfo will generally fail. Thus it is good to call this function as a check before calling GetMessageFcnInfo.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.FactorManager.FactorInfo.GetMessageFcnInfo(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.FactorManager,System.String,System.String,System.Collections.Generic.IDictionary{System.String,System.Type},System.Collections.Generic.IDictionary{System.String,System.Boolean})
member.summary: Get metadata for an operator method.
member.param: Can be null, to mean all parameters.
A mapping from factor arguments to message types. Missing entries imply no constraint. Can be null.
A mapping from factor arguments to bool. Missing entries imply no constraint. Can be null.
member.remarks: This routine caches its results so it tends to be faster than GetMessageFcnInfos. Besides the factor arguments, should include an entry for the return type ("result"). For composite array arguments, should include an entry for the result index ("resultIndex").
member.exception: The best matching type parameters did not satisfy the constraints of the generic method.
No match was found.
The message function is not supported (as opposed to simply missing).
More than one method matches the given constraints.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.FactorManager.FactorInfo.GetMessageFcnInfos

member.summary: Get metadata for multiple operator methods.
member.param: Can be null, to mean all suffixes.
Can be null, to mean all edges.

A mapping from factor arguments to message types. Missing entries imply no constraint. If parameterTypes is null, the result may contain open type parameters. Otherwise the result will not have open type parameters.
member.returns: A non-empty stream of MessageFcnInfos that match the given constraints.
member.remarks: If targetKey is null and parameterTypes is empty, then all operator methods with the given suffix are returned. The results are not cached. For fast retrieval of a single message function, use GetMessageFcnInfo instead. If no message functions match the constraints, one of the below exceptions is thrown.
member.exception: The best matching type parameters did not satisfy the constraints of the generic method.
No match was found.
The message function is not supported (as opposed to simply missing).

member.summary: A stream of MessageFcnInfos matching given constraints.
member.param: The types to scan for methods.
Can be null, to mean all suffixes.
Can be null, to mean all parameters.
A mapping from factor type argument names to types. Missing entries imply no constraint.

A mapping from factor parameter names to types. Missing entries imply no constraint. If parameterTypes is null, the result may contain type parameters of the message function. Otherwise the result will not have type parameters.
A list that collects matching errors.
member.returns: A stream of MessageFcnInfos that match the given constraints.
member.remarks: If targetKey is null, methodSuffix is null, typeArguments is empty, and parameterTypes is empty, then all methods of the given operators are returned.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.FactorManager.FactorInfo.GetDependencyInfo(System.Reflection.MethodInfo,MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.MessageFcnInfo)
member.summary: Get a list of parameter expressions required by this method.
member.param: Dictionary mapping parameter name to edge
member.returns: A DependencyInformation where only (Dependencies,Requirements,Triggers) fields are filled in.

Each dependency expression has one of the following forms:
parameter
parameter[resultIndex]
AllExcept(parameter,resultIndex)
AnyItem(parameter)
AnyItem(AllExcept(parameter,resultIndex))
Any(expr,expr,...)

member.summary: Collect the FactorEdges that this message function depends on.

On return, a list of FactorEdges that must be non-uniform.
member.returns: FactorEdges listed in the order of the parameters to the method.
member.remarks: Factor parameter dependencies are detected via the parameter names of the method. Array index dependencies are specified via parameter attributes.

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.FactorEdge
member.summary: Represents a range of arguments to a factor.

remarks.para: Depending on which fields are non-null, this class represents a variety of different types of factor edge. The simplest type is the name of a parameter. For an array parameter, this implies all elements of the array. The second type is "Param[i]", a specific element of an array parameter. The third type is "Param-[i]", which represents all elements of an array except one.

member.name: F:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.FactorEdge.ParameterName
member.summary: The name of a parameter to the factor function, or its return value. Note that the message "to_x" has ParameterName="x" and IsOutgoingMessage=true.

member.name: F:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.FactorEdge.IsOutgoingMessage
member.summary: True if the argument is of type "to_parameter".

member.name: F:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.FactorEdge.containsOthers
member.summary: True if the range definitely includes items other than Index.

member.name: F:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.FactorEdge.containsIndex
member.summary: True if the range definitely includes the item at Index.

member.name: F:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.FactorEdge.MinCount
member.summary: The minimum number of items in the range.
member.remarks: MinCount must be >= ContainsIndex + ContainsOthers. If ContainsOthers == false, MinCount can only be 0 or 1. MinCount can be 1 even if ContainsOthers == false and ContainsIndex == false. If ContainsOthers == true, MinCount == int.MaxValue means that all items other than Index are in the range.

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.ChannelTransform
member.summary: Transforms variable references into channels, by duplicating variables. A channel is a variable which is assigned once and referenced only once. It corresponds to an edge in a factor graph.

member.summary: Records information about the variable to channel transformation.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.ChannelTransform.ConvertFor(MicrosoftResearch.Transforms.CodeModel.Interfaces.IForStatement)

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.ChannelInfo
member.summary: Describes a channel, i.e. an edge in a factor graph.

remarks.para: A channel connects a model variable to a factor. A channel is either a definition, a use, or a replicated use of a model variable.
A definition channel connects a model variable to its unique defining factor. A definition channel appears in the inference program as a program variable having the same type as the model variable.

A use channel connects a model variable to a child factor. A use channel appears in the inference program as an array of the variable type. It is indexed via [usage indices][variable indices] where the variable indices are only needed if the variable is an array.

All uses of a model variable are given the same ChannelInfo and packed into an array in the inference program. For example, if a model variable x has type double and 2 uses, its usage channels will be declared together as double[] x_uses = new double[3]; and referred to as x_uses[0] and x_uses[1].

The model variable type can be an array, in which case each channel is an array. For example, if a model variable x has type double[] and 2 uses, its usage channels will be declared together as double[][] x_uses = new double[2][]; and referred to as x_uses[0] and x_uses[1].

If the model variable is inside of a plate, then all instances of the channel share the same ChannelInfo and are packed into a nested array in the inference program. For example, if a model variable x is in a plate of size 3 and has 2 uses, its usage channels will be declared together as double[][] x_uses = new double[2][]; and x_uses[0] refers to the first use of x in the plate.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.DeadCodeTransform.CollectUses(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Graphs.IndexedGraph,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Int32})
member.summary: Returns all nodes in the schedule whose target appears prior to the node.
Remove nodes from the cyclic schedule whose result does not reach usedNodes.
member.param: On entry, the set of nodes whose value is needed at the end of the schedule. On exit, the set of nodes whose value is needed at the beginning of the schedule.
On entry, the set of nodes whose value is used only by itself (due to a cyclic dependency). On exit, the set of nodes whose value is used only by itself.
On exit, a special schedule to use for the final iteration. Empty if the final schedule is the same as the regular schedule.
member.remarks: We cannot simply do a graph search because we want to compute reachability with respect to the nodes that are actually on the schedule.

member.summary: Remove nodes from the schedule whose result does not reach usedNodes.

member.returns: A subset of the schedule, in the same order.

Stores the name and type of the target variable, if it is not already declared. Otherwise null.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Models.ModelBuilder.BuildRandVar``1(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Models.Variable{``0})
member.summary: Add the definition of a random variable to the MSL, inside of the necessary containers.
member.remarks: A scalar variable is declared and defined in one line such as: int x = factor(...);. An array variable is first declared with an initializer such as: int[] array = new int[4];. Then it is defined either with a bulk factor such as: array = factor(...);, or it is defined via its item variable. An item variable is defined by 'for' loop whose body is: array[i] = factor(...);.

member.summary: Attribute which indicates that the output message will be recovered from the targetted variable. The output message of a variable is its marginal divided by its inbox message, and is used in situations where variables are shared between different models

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.DerivedVariable
member.summary: For expert use only! When sharing a variable between multiple models (e.g. using SharedVariable) you can add this attribute to have the variable be treated as a derived variable, even if it is not derived in the submodel where it appears.

member.summary: Counter used to generate variable names.

member.summary: Stores information about how a statement depends on other statements.

member.name: F:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.DependencyInformation.dependencyTypeOf
member.summary: Stores the dependency type of all dependent statements.

member.name: F:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.DependencyInformation.offsetIndexOf
member.summary: Stores the offsets of all dependent statements that have an offset.

member.name: F:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.DependencyInformation.IsOutput
member.summary: True if this statement assigns to an output variable of the inference.

member.name: F:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.DependencyInformation.IsUniform
member.summary: True if this statement always returns a uniform distribution or zero evidence value.

member.name: F:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.DependencyInformation.IsFresh
member.summary: True if this statement must be updated whenever any dependency changes.

member.name: F:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.DependencyInformation.ParameterDependencies
member.summary: List of method arguments that the statement depends on.

member.name: P:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.DependencyInformation.Dependencies
member.summary: Statements that modify variables used in this statement. Excludes initializers and allocations.

member.name: P:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.DependencyInformation.DeclDependencies
member.summary: Statements that allocate (or in some cases initialize) variables used in this statement.
member.remarks: DeclDependencies and Dependencies must be disjoint.

member.name: P:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.DependencyInformation.ContainerDependencies
member.summary: Statements that modify variables used in the containers of this statement.

member.name: P:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.DependencyInformation.FreshDependencies
member.summary: Statements which must be up-to-date before executing this statement.

member.name: P:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.DependencyInformation.Requirements
member.summary: Statements that must be executed before this statement.
member.remarks: AnyStatements can be used to create disjunctive requirements, e.g. "either A or B must execute before this statement".

member.name: P:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.DependencyInformation.SkipIfUniform
member.summary: Statements that must be executed before this statement, and must return a non-uniform result.
member.remarks: AnyStatements can be used to create disjunctive requirements, e.g. "either A or B must execute before this statement".

member.name: P:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.DependencyInformation.Initializers
member.summary: Initialization statements of the variable that this statement mutates.

member.name: P:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.DependencyInformation.Triggers
member.summary: Statements whose execution invalidates the result of this statement.

member.name: F:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.DependencyType.Dependency
member.summary: Statements that modify variables used in this statement. Excludes initializers and allocations.

member.name: F:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.DependencyType.Requirement
member.summary: Statements that must be executed before this statement.
member.remarks: AnyStatements can be used to create disjunctive requirements, e.g. "either A or B must execute before this statement".

member.name: F:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.DependencyType.SkipIfUniform
member.summary: Statements that must be executed before this statement, and must return a non-uniform result.
member.remarks: AnyStatements can be used to create disjunctive requirements, e.g. "either A or B must execute before this statement".

member.name: F:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.DependencyType.Trigger
member.summary: Statements whose execution invalidates the result of this statement.

member.name: F:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.DependencyType.Fresh
member.summary: Statements which must be up-to-date before executing this statement.

member.summary: Statements that allocate (or in some cases initialize) variables used in this statement.
member.remarks: DeclDependencies and Dependencies must be disjoint.

member.summary: Statements that modify variables used in the containers of this statement.

member.summary: Allows the algorithm to modify the attributes on a factor. For example, in Gibbs sampling different message types are passed depending on the context. member.name: F:Microsoft.Dynamic.Conversion.SubclassCount
member.summary: The number of subclass edges between the two types.
member.remarks: This is only valid if converter is null, i.e. no conversion is needed. If the two types are the same, then SubclassCount == 0. If one is a direct subclass of the other, SubclassCount == 1. If one is a subclass of a subclass of the other, SubclassCount == 2, and so on.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Dynamic.Conversion.IsExplicit
member.summary: True if the conversion is explicit.
member.remarks: Must be false if converter is null. An implicit conversion must always succeed and does not lose information. Otherwise, it is explicit.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Dynamic.Conversion.op_LessThan(Microsoft.Dynamic.Conversion,Microsoft.Dynamic.Conversion)
member.summary: True if A is a more specific conversion than B.
member.returns: True if A is a more specific conversion than B.
member.remarks: The following criteria are applied in order: 1. A null conversion versus a non-null conversion. 2. Among null conversions, the one crossing fewer subclass links. 3. An implicit conversion versus an explicit conversion.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Dynamic.Conversion.GetWeight
member.summary: Returns a numerical weight such that (a.GetWeight() < b.GetWeight()) iff (a < b)

member.returns: A new array of rank toRank with the same contents as fromArray.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Dynamic.Conversion.TryGetConversion(System.Type,System.Type,Microsoft.Dynamic.Conversion@)
member.summary: Get a type converter.
member.param: non-null. May contain type parameters. Use typeof(Nullable) to convert from a null value.
non-null. May contain type parameters. May be typeof(void), for which no conversion is needed.
member.returns: null if no converter was found.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Dynamic.Conversion.ConvertDelegate(System.Type,System.Delegate)
member.summary: Convert a weakly-typed delegate into a strongly-typed delegate.
member.param: A delegate with parameters (object[] args). The return type can be any type convertible to the return type of delegateType, or void if the delegateType is void.
member.returns: A delegate of type delegateType. The arguments of this delegate will be passed as (object[]) args to the innerMethod.

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Graphs.CyclicDependencySort`2
member.summary: Order the nodes to best satisfy cyclic dependencies.

remarks.p: The algorithm is essentially a topological sort, modified to deal with cycles. In case of a directed cycle, we search for a node which can execute before some of its parents. This judgement is made by the canExecute predicate.

Algorithm: For each target node, we run bfs backward to collect a list of ancestors and their finishing times. These ancestor nodes are placed in a priority queue according to their finishing time. We then examine each node on the queue to determine if its input requirements are satisfied. If so, the node is scheduled. If not, we put it aside to wait until one of its unscheduled parents is scheduled.
SourcesOf and CreateNodeData are the only graph methods used. The Nodes property is not used.

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Graphs.CyclicDependencySort`2.CostUpdater
member.summary: Called to update the cost of scheduling a node.
member.param: The previous cost, which may be modified in place for efficiency. May be null.

member.name: F:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Graphs.CyclicDependencySort`2.IsScheduled
member.summary: Indicates if the node has been placed on the schedule.
member.remarks: Unlike WasScheduledLastIteration, this information changes throughout the scheduling process.

member.name: F:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Graphs.CyclicDependencySort`2.StopScheduling
member.summary: Indicates if scheduling should stop. Takes the latest node to be scheduled.

member.name: F:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Graphs.CyclicDependencySort`2.MaxScheduledCost
member.summary: The maximum cost of a scheduled node.

member.name: F:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Graphs.CyclicDependencySort`2.ApplyThreshold
member.summary: Indicates that only nodes whose cost is less than Threshold will be scheduled.

member.name: F:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Graphs.CyclicDependencySort`2.addToSchedule
member.summary: Called just before IsScheduled[node] is set to true.

member.name: F:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Graphs.CyclicDependencySort`2.queue
member.summary: Queue of nodes waiting to be scheduled.

member.name: P:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Graphs.CyclicDependencySort`2.Threshold
member.summary: Cost at which nodes will not be scheduled.

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.ModelAnalysisTransform
member.summary: Transform which analyses the model to determine stochasticity and to set other attributes where possible.
member.remarks: The analysis sets the following attributes where appropriate: - Stochastic: on declarations for variables which are determined to be stochastic. - IsConstant: on declarations for variables which are determined to be constant. - MarginalPrototype: on declarations for stochastic variables where the marginal prototype can be determined automatically. The transform also processes and removes any Attrib static calls, replacing them with attributes on the appropriate code elements.

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.GroupTransform
member.summary: The group transform deals with all aspects of group handling It creates groups as necessary for deterministic factors and constraints and changes the group annotations into MessagePath annotations on factor expressions. It also creates related annotations (ChannelPath attributes) on variable declarations so that the message transform knows what type of variables to create.
member.remarks:
The group transform has the following steps:
1. Builds a bipartite factor graph of factors and variables. This is done using the transform framework. This will also create groups for deterministic factors and constraints
2. For each existing group (i.e. manually specified group) consisting of more than one variable expression, picks a variable, and finds the shortest path from that variable to all other variables in the group. Add all nodes in the path to the group.
3a. For any deterministic factor which is not a variable factor, creates a group for each input argument, and add the output argument (unless such a pair exists) 3b. Similarly for constraints, where the first argument to the constraint acts as the output argument.
4. For each variable factor, if any argument is in a group, ensures that all other arguments are in the group.
5. Finds the root of each group. With the current architecture, the root variable cannot be on the 'uses' side of any other variable in the group. This is because 'uses' are currently treated as a whole in terms of type, and if one of the uses (or anything downstream) were picked as the root, then one of the uses would need to be a different type. The exception to this is GateExitRandom which is used for variables defined within a gate - in this case, the root must be the exit side.
NOTE: In future, it would be nice to have a factor which allowed one of the uses to be treated differently from all the other uses. This factor could then be inserted in situations where roots were manually specified the uses side of any variable in the group. This would require that the Group transform should go before the Channel transform so that we can insert the correct type of variable factor
6. Calculates distances from the root for each group
7. Loops through the factor expressions, and call the algorithm to set the paths. for the MessagePath attributes. This is done whether or not the expression participates in a group.
8. Traverses the factor graph to create the ChannelPath attributes

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.InferenceEngine.GetCompiledInferenceAlgorithm(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Models.IVariable[])
member.summary: Returns a compiled algorithm which can later be used to infer marginal distributions for the specified variables. This method allows more fine-grained control over the inference procedure.
member.remarks: This method should not be used unless fine-grained control over the inference is required. Infer.NET will cache the last compiled algorithm and re-use it if possible.
member.param: The variables whose marginals are to be computed by the returned algorithm.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.InferenceEngine.GetRelevantModelExpressions(MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Models.IVariable[])
member.summary: For advanced use. Returns all the model expressions that are relevant to inferring the set of variables provided. This may be useful for constructing visualisations of the model.
member.remarks: The returned collection includes Variable and VariableArray objects which the engine has determined are relevant to inferring marginals over the variables provided. This will at least include the provided variables, but may include other relevant variables as well. It will also include MethodInvoke objects which act as priors, constraints or factors in the model.
member.param: The variables to build a model for

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Graphs.PathFinder`1
member.summary: Find all elementary paths of a directed graph

remarks.para: The paths are described by firing actions according to the pattern: BeginPath, AddNode, AddNode, ..., AddNode, EndPath, BeginPath, ..., EndPath. The node on a path will appear in order of the directed edges between them.
Only paths which cannot be made longer are returned, i.e. sub-paths of an elementary path are not returned.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Graphs.PathFinder`1.SearchFrom(`0)
member.summary: Find all paths starting with the given node

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Graphs.PathFinder`2
member.summary: Find all elementary paths of a directed graph

remarks.para: The paths are described by firing actions according to the pattern: BeginPath, AddEdge, AddEdge, ..., AddEdge, EndPath, BeginPath, ..., EndPath. The edges on a path will appear in order of their directions.
Only paths which cannot be made longer are returned, i.e. sub-paths of an elementary path are not returned.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Graphs.PathFinder`2.SearchFrom(`0)
member.summary: Find all paths starting with the given node

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Graphs.Graph`1
member.summary: A directed graph of HasTargets objects.

remarks.p: Abstractly, a directed graph is a collection of node pairs (node1,node2). Each pair is called an edge. An edge from a node to itself (a self-loop) is allowed. Duplicate edges are allowed. Edges to nodes outside of the graph are allowed.
A node is added via g.Nodes.Add(node) and an edge is added via g.AddEdge(node1,node2).
This implementation supports node labels, which can be any object. A labeled node is added via g.Nodes.WithLabel(label).Add(node).

The graph is implemented by an adjacency list which can be singly or doubly-linked. The list is distributed among the nodes of the graph, which hold their child nodes and possibly also their parent nodes (in the doubly-linked case). Nodes which implement the HasSources interface will be doubly-linked, and other nodes will be singly-linked. Thus the graph can be part doubly-linked and part singly-linked. Doubly-linked nodes are more efficient to remove from the graph.

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Graphs.Graph`1.Data`2
member.summary: Provides node and edge data for an existing graph.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Graphs.Graph`1.AddEdge(`0,`0)
member.summary: Add a directed edge from node to target.
member.remarks: The two nodes need not be in the graph, and will not be added to the graph.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Graphs.Graph`1.RemoveEdge(`0,`0)
member.summary: Remove a directed edge from source to target.
member.remarks: If there are multiple edges from source to target, only one is removed.

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Graphs.IGraph`2
member.summary: A graph with explicit edge handles.
member.typeparam: The type of a node handle.
The type of an edge handle.

remarks.p: This interface is intended for use by generic algorithms which can operate on any graph type. Nodes and edges are treated as opaque handles, generated by the graph, which only the graph knows how to resolve. As a consequence, the methods AddEdge(EdgeType) and ContainsEdge(EdgeType) are not necessarily supported, because in order to use them, you would have to have a valid edge handle, which implies the edge already exists in the graph.

This interface can be used for both directed and undirected graphs, though the methods only provide undirected information (i.e. all edges rather than in-edges vs. out-edges). See for methods to modify a graph, and to get directed edge information.

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Graphs.CycleFinder`1
member.summary: Find all elementary cycles of a directed graph

remarks.para: The cycles are described by firing actions according to the pattern: BeginCycle, AddNode, AddNode, ..., AddNode, EndCycle, BeginCycle, ..., EndCycle. The nodes in a cycle will appear in order of the directed edges between them.

The algorithm comes from: "Finding all the Elementary Circuits of a Directed Graph" Donald B. Johnson SIAM Journal on Computing (1975) http://dutta.csc.ncsu.edu/csc791_spring07/wrap/circuits_johnson.pdf The runtime is O((n+e)(c+1)) where n is the number of nodes, e is the number of edges, and c is the number of cycles in the graph.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Graphs.CycleFinder`1.SearchFrom(`0,`0)
member.summary: Find cycles containing root

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Graphs.CycleFinder`2
member.summary: Find all elementary cycles of a directed graph

remarks.para: The cycles are described by firing actions according to the pattern: BeginCycle, AddEdge, AddEdge, ..., AddEdge, EndCycle, BeginCycle, ..., EndCycle. The edges in a cycle will appear in order of their directions.

The algorithm comes from: "Finding all the Elementary Circuits of a Directed Graph" Donald B. Johnson SIAM Journal on Computing (1975) http://dutta.csc.ncsu.edu/csc791_spring07/wrap/circuits_johnson.pdf The runtime is O((n+e)(c+1)) where n is the number of nodes, e is the number of edges, and c is the number of cycles in the graph.

member.name: M:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Graphs.CycleFinder`2.SearchFrom(`0)
member.summary: Find cycles containing root

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Graphs.LabeledEdgeGraph`2
member.summary: A directed graph of HasTargets objects.

remarks.para: This implementation of graphs also supports edge labels, which can be any object. Thus an edge is actually a triple (node1,node2,label). If not specified, the label defaults to an empty string (""). Similar to hash keys, edge labels should not change once the edge is added to the graph. Instead you must delete the edge and add it back with a new label. Edge labels can be used analogously to properties in C#. That is, node1 can link to node2 via the label "Parent", to indicate that node2 is the parent of node1. This allows graphs to represent typed linkage structures similar to hand-coded C# object structures. See BinaryTree.cs for an example.

Edge labels are not meant to replace edge objects. If you want a graph with explicit mutable edge objects, make these objects into nodes with properties Head and Tail. Then make a bipartite graph between the intended node objects and the intended edge objects, using these properties as the edge labels. You can also create hypergraphs this way.

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Models.SharedVariableArray2D`2
member.summary: A helper class that represents a variable array which is shared between multiple models. For example, where a very large model has been divided into sections corresponding to batches of data, an instance of this class can be used to help learn each parameter shared between the batches.

remarks.para: Shared variable arrays are used as follows. First the shared variable array is created with a prior distribution. Then a copy is created for each model using the method. Each model has a BatchCount which is the number of data batches you want to process with that model. Before performing inference in each model and batch, should be called for each shared variable. After all shared variables have their inputs set, should then be called for each model and batch. These two steps are done automatically by . For inference to converge, you must loop multiple times through all the models, calling or SetInput/InferOutput each time. At any point the current marginal of the shared variable array can be retrieved using .

In some situations, shared variable arrays cannot be created directly from a prior distribution, for example in a hierarchical model. In these situations, create the shared variable array with a uniform prior, and use to define the variable.

member.typeparam: The domain type of an array element
The marginal distribution type of the array

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Transforms.DependencyAnalysisTransform
member.summary: Attaches DependencyInformation attributes to all statements in the input program.
member.remarks:
Dependency analysis operates in two passes:
1. Each statement is analysed to determine if it declares or mutates a variable or array element. All such declaring/mutating statements are cached against the variable or array declaration element. The mutation can be quite complex for jagged arrays. Any previous statement which mutates the same variable as the current statement is considered as and marked as an 'allocation' (for example there may be many allocation statements defining a jagged array). These previous statements are added as dependencies on the current statement
Dependencies are marked using a DependencyInformation attribute stored against each statement. Dependencies are represented as either statements or as reference expressions.
2. Using the statement cache prepared above, any expression dependencies are converted into statement dependencies by finding all statements which mutate the expression and are not marked as 'allocations'. Declaration dependencies are added on statements marked as allocations. After this process, all DependencyInformation attributes contain only dependencies on statements.
member.summary: Analyses expressions to determine their dependencies.

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Graphs.StrongComponents`1
member.summary: Find the strongly connected components of a directed graph.

remarks.para: A strongly connected component is a maximal set of nodes that can all reach each other by a directed path. Every directed graph has a unique partition of nodes into strongly connected components. The components form a DAG, since there cannot be any directed cycle among the components.

Given a graph and a set of start nodes, this class enumerates the strongly connected components that are reachable from the start nodes. The components are described by firing actions according to the pattern: BeginComponent, AddNode, AddNode, ..., AddNode, EndComponent, BeginComponent, ..., EndComponent. The nodes in a component will appear in an arbitrary order. The components will appear in topological order, i.e. there are no edges from a later component to an earlier component.
The implementation uses depth first search in each direction (Kosaraju's algorithm), as described by Cormen, Leiserson, and Rivest.

member.name: T:MicrosoftResearch.Infer.Graphs.StrongComponents2`1
member.summary: Find the strongly connected components of a directed graph.

remarks.para: A strongly connected component is a maximal set of nodes that can all reach each other by a directed path. Every directed graph has a unique partition of nodes into strongly connected components. The components form a DAG, since there cannot be any directed cycle among the components.

Given a graph and a set of start nodes, this class enumerates the strongly connected components that are reachable from the start nodes. The components are described by firing actions according to the pattern: BeginComponent, AddNode, AddNode, ..., AddNode, EndComponent, BeginComponent, ..., EndComponent. The nodes in a component will appear in an arbitrary order. The components will appear in reverse topological order, i.e. there are no edges from an earlier component to a later component.

The implementation uses Pierce's algorithm (a modification of Tarjan's algorithm): "An Improved Algorithm for Finding the Strongly Connected Components of a Directed Graph" David J. Pearce, Technical Report, 2005 http://www.mcs.vuw.ac.nz/~djp/files/P05.ps
